title: 115_hr2214
content: The Act titled "Government Shutdown Accountability and Economic Report Act of 2017" prohibits the pay of members of Congress during a government shutdown. The "Government Shutdown Accountability and Economic Report Act of 2017" prohibits the pay of members of Congress during a government shutdown by deducting a day's worth of pay for each 24-hour period of the shutdown from their compensation. The "Government Shutdown Accountability and Economic Report Act of 2017" mandates that during a government shutdown, members of Congress will have their pay withheld for each day of the shutdown, starting from November 2018. During a government shutdown, members of Congress will have their pay withheld for each day of the shutdown, based on the annual rate of pay and the number of 24-hour periods the shutdown is in effect. The withheld amounts will be deposited in an escrow account and released at the end of the Congress to ensure compliance with the Constitution. During a government shutdown, members of Congress will have their pay withheld and deposited in an escrow account. Any remaining amounts in the account will be released at the end of the One Hundred Fifteenth Congress. The Secretary of the Treasury will assist payroll administrators in carrying out this process. The subsection does not apply after the general election in November 2018. During a government shutdown, members of Congress will have their pay withheld and deposited in an escrow account, managed by designated officials from the House of Representatives and the Senate. The term "Member of Congress" is defined as an individual serving in a specific position under the Legislative Reorganization Act of 1946. The Congressional Budget Office will provide reports on the economic costs and costs to taxpayers of a government shutdown. The Director of the Congressional Budget Office will submit a report to Congress within 24 hours of a Government shutdown, estimating economic losses, decrease in GDP, unprovided assistance by the Small Business Administration, and lost revenue for the National Park Service due to closures. The Congressional Budget Office will estimate economic losses, decrease in GDP, unprovided assistance by the Small Business Administration, and lost revenue for National Park Service lands and historic sites during a Government shutdown, including revenue lost due to effects on tourism and travel. Government shutdown is defined as a lapse in appropriations for any Federal agency or department due to a failure to enact a regular appropriations bill or continuing resolution.
